summary: A letter from New York Daily News reporter Stephen Rex Brown to Judge Katherine Polk Failla requesting the unsealing of transcripts and documents related to the case of Efrain Reyes, who was the last person to share a cell with Jeffrey Epstein. The letter argues for public access under First Amendment principles and notes Reyes's death.

persons.name: Stephen Rex Brown
persons.role: Reporter for New York Daily News
persons.context: Author of the letter requesting unsealing of court documents related to Efrain Reyes's case, citing public interest and First Amendment rights.

persons.name: Katherine Polk Failla
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case who is being asked to unseal proceedings and documents related to Efrain Reyes.

persons.name: Efrain Reyes
persons.context: The subject of the criminal case who died; he was the last person to share a cell with Jeffrey Epstein, generating public interest.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned as the person with whom Efrain Reyes last shared a cell, which is the basis for public interest in Reyes's case.

connections.description: Reyes was the last person to share a cell with Jeffrey Epstein, as noted in the letter.
Brown is addressing Judge Failla in a formal request to unseal court documents.

events.title: Reyes's Change of Plea Hearing
events.description: Efrain Reyes's change of plea hearing, the transcript of which is under seal.

events.title: Reyes's Sentencing
events.description: Sentencing proceeding for Efrain Reyes, with transcript under seal.

events.title: Death of Efrain Reyes
events.description: Efrain Reyes died at his mother's apartment in the Bronx the month prior to the letter (November 2020).

keyFacts: Efrain Reyes was the last person to share a cell with Jeffrey Epstein, which is why his case is of public interest.
Reyes died in November 2020 at his mother's apartment in the Bronx.
Transcripts of Reyes's change of plea hearing (August 26, 2019) and sentencing (April 13, 2020) are under seal.
The letter argues for unsealing based on First Amendment right of access to court proceedings and judicial documents.
Judge Katherine Polk Failla is asked to unseal the documents or make a finding on record for keeping them sealed.
